loans.name: Kudakwake

texts.en:
Kudakwake is 23 years old and lives in the Wedza District of Zimbabwe. She is married with one son. She is running a business of buying and selling kitchen utensils, clothes and shoes. She wants to be financially stable and look after her family. The business is located at the shopping center and it is very convenient and promising. Kudakwake volunteers on a weekly basis as a Learner Guide at the local secondary school, helping students with their studies. 

With a Kiva loan she would like to rent a stall at the flea market and stock it up with dresses, jackets, skirts, shirts and kitchenware to increase sales and profit to support her son.

loans.use: To rent a stall at the flea market and stock it up with dresses, jackets, skirts, shirts and kitchenware to increase sales and profit to support her son.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy enough dishes to sell.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen resides in Hoima, Uganda. He is aged 62 and married with four children who are all adults. He owns cattle, and he makes extra income through farming. He started this business to develop himself. His hopes for the future are to build a residential house and have a good retirement. Weather changes affect his business, especially during the dry season when his cattle have no grass to eat. He is an honest hard working man who will use the loan to buy a motorcycle for transportation.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle for transportation

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a 40-year-old lady who is married, and together they have been blessed with one child who is in school. She is a crop and animal farmer and she has been in this business for the last 10 years. She makes a monthly income of 15,000 Kenyan shillings (KES).

This is her first loan with Visionfund Kenya after she joined an existing group. She plans to use the loan to buy seeds, fertilizers and spray chemicals, and to pay for labor to help with farming. She hopes to make good returns which she will save towards her child's education.

In future she would like to be a large scale farmer who supplies farm produce to other people, and to become financially stable.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers and spray chemicals, and to pay for labor

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome is a 30-year-old woman, married to Patrick, who adds additional income to their family. They are blessed with three children. Salome has been running a grocery stall for a period of five years, earning her an income of about KES 15,000 at the end of every month.

She is now servicing her 4th loan of KES 60,000 with VisionFund Kenya and intends to use the whole amount to add additional stock of vegetables, cabbages, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes and onions to sell to her customers on a daily basis.

Salome plans to use the anticipated income to pay school fees for her children and hopes to build a permanent grocery stall.

loans.use: To buy vegetables, cabbages, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes and onions to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy a bag of flour and a bag of sugar to sell.

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en:
Alfred is 38 years old and married with four children and two dependents, his parents who are aged. He deals in goat rearing as his major source of income and also does cattle fattening as another source of income on a small scale.  He has been in this business for eight years.  He has managed to provide his family with the basic needs of life. However his major challenge is limited land for goat rearing.

Alfred is applying for a loan of Shs 3,000,000 to buy land and goats for rearing.  He wants to be the leading supplier of high quality goats in his region and see his children attend education.

Alfred is honest and hardworking.

loans.use: To buy land and goats for rearing

loans.name: Simon

texts.en: Simon lives in Hoima, Uganda. He is aged 48 and is married with three children all attending school. He owns a retail shop, but raises extra income through poultry and coffee farming. He started this business to generate income for his family. Bad weather and poultry diseases like chicken pox are a hindrance to his business. Simon will use the loan to buy chicks for his poultry farm.

loans.use: to buy chicks for his poultry farm

loans.name: Mathias

texts.en: Mathias lives in Hoima, Uganda. He is aged 58 and married with 15 children, 7 of whom attend school. He owns a secretarial service shop and makes extra income through his retail shop of general merchandise, such as rice, sugar, salt and soap. He started this business for personal development. His plan for the future is buying a car to ease his travels. Mathias intends to use the loan to buy more soap, matchboxes and salt to sell.

loans.use: to buy more soap, matchboxes and salt to sell

loans.name: John Baptist

texts.en:
John Baptist is 36 years old and married with three children and four dependents, his parents who are aged and two brothers at university. John deals in produce, especially in selling dried beans as his major source of income. His wife is a teacher by profession and earns salary at the end of the month as another source of income. He has managed to provide his family with the basic necessities of life and has constructed a permanent house for his family.

John Baptist is applying for a loan of 2,500,000 UGX for topping up and buying a car as a taxi as another source of income. His major challenge is inadequate income to pay school fees for the brothers at university due to an increase in their fee structure which leaves his business in a decline. His dream is to see all his children and siblings graduate from the university.

John is honest and a hardworking man.

loans.use: to top up his savings and buy a car as a taxi

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy an air conditioner and sewing machine and to renovate his workplace.

loans.name: Sibongile

texts.en:
Sibongile is 31 years old and married with three children. She lives in Chiredzi District, Zimbabwe. She has been volunteering as a Camfed Learner Guide, teaching life skills in local schools. 

In addition, Sibongile sells products such as jackets, shoes, jeans, shirts, skirts and T-shirts at the local flea market. With a Kiva loan, Sibongile will purchase more bags, shoes, jeans, shirts, skirts, track suits and T-shirts to increase her stock and increase her sales and profits. 

Sibongile wants to grow the business to provide for her family’s basic needs and enhance their quality of life.

loans.use: to buy more clothes and bags

loans.name: Las Perlitas Group

texts.en:
From a rural community of Totonicapan, in the Southwestern part of Guatemala, we are happy to present the Friendship Bridge Trust Bank “Las Perlitas”, meaning “The Little Pearls”. The group is composed of ten women who are starting another loan cycle through Friendship Bridge. They are hopeful that Kiva investors will fund their loan.

Maria is the treasurer of the Trust Bank and a member of the Board of Directors. She is forty years old and the mother of four children who range in age from eight to twenty years. Maria designs and creates traditional clothing such as aprons and blouses called “huipiles”. She learned how to do this several years ago. She sells what she fabricates and business is going quite well. For this reason, Maria has hired two additional people from her community so that she can meet the demand of her customers. She is requesting a new loan that she will use to purchase supplies for her business, including a variety of good quality thread. She wants to be certain to have enough raw materials on hand. Maria sells her textiles two or three times each week. Her customers are well aware of the high quality of her clothing and they are most faithful. Maria tries to charge a good price, one that is good for her and for her customers.

Maria is very enthusiastic as treasurer of the group and wants to improve her leadership skills, which in turn will help her self-esteem. The entire Trust Bank is very excited to begin a new loan cycle that will include additional educational trainings about women’s leadership and women’s rights, business management practices, nutrition, health and hygiene as well as self-esteem. These trainings are given once each month by a Friendship Bridge Loan Officer in their own indigenous language in their own rural community. They are quite comfortable with the setting of their meetings and this makes them feel safe to communicate and to participate. Friendship Bridge calls the combination of the small loans and education “Microcredit Plus”.

Both Maria and her colleagues appreciate the confidence of Kiva investors, because the investment helps to build their future by improving their life conditions. Thanks Kiva.

loans.use: to purchase supplies for her textile business including a variety of good quality thread.

loans.name: Oscar Armando

texts.es: Oscar de 55 años de edad se dedica desde hace varios a la agricultura su principal siembra es el maíz, cuando su cosecha ya esta lista la almacena en los graneros que muestra la fotografía para luego comercializarlos en los diferentes mercados que se encuentran cerca de su lugar de residencia, con lo que obtiene de sus ventas logra solventar algunos gastos de su hogar, Oscar vive en casa propia con su esposa y sus hijos, el está solicitando un crédito para la compra de semillas, fertilizantes, abonos, controles de plagas, etc. para poder continuar con sus cultivos y darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Oscar is 55 years old, he has made a living for several years from agriculture. His main crop is corn, when his crop is ready he stores it in the barns that are shown in the photograph, and then sells it in the different markets that are found near his place of residency. With the earnings from the sales, he can solve some of the household expenses. 

Oscar lives in his own house with his wife and children. He is requesting a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers, manure, plague control etc. to be able to continue with his crops and give his family a better quality of life.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers, manure, plague control, etc.

loans.name: Annet

texts.en: Annet is a 39-year-old married woman with five children. She used her previous loan to buy clothes to sell. She still sells new clothes in her shop, but also takes them around to offices when her customers find it hard to come to her. While she says she has inadequate access to capital, her business growth is also affected by changes in fashions and designs. Annet is determined to transform her business, take it to greater heights, and make more profits. That is why she is asking for a loan to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: 0508 Đông Vệ Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Hoa operates a food stall/restaurant, selling breakfast. She is requesting a loan to purchase more food to cook breakfast to sell.

Hoa is 37 years old and she is married, with two children. She is the group leader of the 0508 Đông Vệ solidarity group, which consists of four members. 

Hoa lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, an urban area in Thanh Hoa province. This is her first loan with the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Hoa has been involved in this business for five years. The main hardship that she faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Hoa hopes for her children to find a good job, for her family to be healthy and happy, and for her business to do well.

loans.use: to purchase more food to cook breakfast to sell.

loans.name: 10 - Quảng Hưng Group

texts.en: Mrs. Tráng works in agriculture raising poultry. She is requesting a loan to buy more baby poultry to raise and sell in the future. She is 52 years old, married and the mother of five children. She also leads the 10 - Quảng Hưng solidarity group, which consists of five members. She lives in Thanh Hoa city, a town in Thanh Hoa province. In 2008, she joined the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business, and has successfully repaid two loans from the fund. She has been in her current line of work for more than ten years and says that her main hardship is a lack of capital. With her profits, Tráng hopes for her business to do well, for her family to be healthy and happy, and to travel for vacation within the country.

loans.use: to purchase more baby poultry to raise and sell in future

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase clothing for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to  buy fruits, vegetables, sugar, wheat flour, baking flour, beans, salt, etc.

loans.name: Sonia Marina

texts.es: Sonia en su afán de poder cumplir su meta de poder darle a sus hijos un futuro digno, con educación, solicita nuevamente un crédito para invertirlo en su negocio de venta de tortillas y frijoles, comprará maíz y leña. El crédito anterior también fue utilizado en la inversión de materia prima lo que le permitió mejorar las ventas y obtener mayores ingresos para la manutención de su familia. Su esposo continua desempeñándose como guarda de seguridad.
texts.en:
Sonia, in her eagerness to fulfill her goal to have the power to give her children a decent future, with education, is requesting another loan to invest in her business of selling tortillas (thin corn flatbread) and beans (she will purchase corn and wood). 

The previous loan was also used to invest in raw material, which allowed her to improve her sales and obtain a greater income to support her family. Her husband continues to work as a security guard.

loans.use: to purchase corn quintals and wood for the preparation of beans

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a pick-up truck, 5-gallon bottles, and other items

loans.name: Koffi

texts.fr:
Koffi, 60 ans, est retraité. Il est marié à une revendeuse et est père de 4 enfants dont le dernier poursuit encore ses études.
A l’heure actuelle, Koffi exploite plusieurs moulins à maïs dans divers quartiers de Lome. Il emploie une personne pour l’aider à gérer ses moulins. Cette activité l’occupe depuis 2012. Les céréales constituent une part importante de l’alimentation togolaise, le développement des moulins permet d’augmenter la productivité de cette étape dans les processus de transformation du maïs en farine et donc de développer l’activité économique du pays.
Koffi aimerait augmenter la taille de son parc de moulins en ajoutant un moulin à ceux qu’il possède déjà. Pour cela, il a besoin d’acheter deux dynamos et différentes pièces, des poulies notamment, permettant de créer des nouveaux moulins. C’est pour cela qu’il sollicite son tout premier crédit.
Koffi souhaite bien sûr voir son activité se développer régulièrement et atteindre un certain stade de prospérité économique. Ceci lui permettra d’obtenir des revenus élevés et stables afin de mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Koffi, aged 60, is retired. He is married to a retailer and is the father of four children, of whom the youngest is still pursuing his studies. At this time, Koffi is making use of several corn mills (grinders) in diverse districts of Lomé. He employs one person to help him manage his mills. He has been in this business since 2012.

Grains constitute an important part of Togolese foods. Developing mills allows for increasing the productivity at this stage, processing corn into cornmeal and thus developing the country’s economic activity. 

Koffi would like to increase the size of his range of mills by adding a mill to those he already owns. To do so, he needs to purchase two generators and different parts, especially pulleys, enabling new mills to be established. His very first loan is being requested for this.

Of course, Koffi would like to see his business develop progressively and to achieve a certain level of economic prosperity. This will enable him to have higher and stable revenues, so as to do better meeting the needs of his family.

loans.use: to purchase a mill (grinder)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: 10-Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en: Mrs. Hà operates a food stall selling vegetables, and is requesting a loan to buy more of them to resell. She is 35 years old and married with two children. She also leads the 10-Nam Ngạn solidarity group, which consists of three members, and lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, a urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with her dependents. In 2010, Hà joined the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business, and has successfully repaid five previous loans the fund. She has been involved in her current work for about a year, and says her main hardship is a lack of capital. With her profits, she hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, for her business to do well, and to buy land of her own.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Angelica

texts.en: Angelica is a 50-year-old hardworking lady with four children living in Fort Portal, Uganda. She deals in selling fresh foods and retail. She started the business in order to employ herself. She faces challenges of competition and perishability of her products. Besides that, she hopes to build a good business and build houses to rent. Angelica needs a loan to buy fresh foods like tomatoes, cabbages and onions to sell.

loans.use: to buy fresh foods like tomatoes, cabbages and onions to sell

loans.name: Celsa

texts.en: Celsa (pictured with her son) is a Kubo Financiero client. She is 50 years old, is married to Edilberto and has two sons ages 16 and 10. Both of their sons go to school. She sells backpacks and other gifts in a flea market in Mexico City. She has been working in this trade for more than 30 years. She is asking for a loan to buy backpacks for the back-to-school season. By buying in volume, she is able to get better prices and increase her profits. Celsa describes herself as hardworking and responsible. She only takes loans to invest in her business and always pays on time.

loans.use: to buy backpacks for the back-to-school season

loans.name: Benkadi 5 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe BENKADI 5 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans, ont en moyenne 3 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles traditionnelles à N'TORLA un village dans la commune de KOLOKOBA dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du MALI.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur septième prêt de campagne avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est l’arachide avec madame DIATA débout à la première position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo dans ce groupe de femme BENKADI 5. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter 1 sac de 50 kg d’engrais, 1 bidon d’herbicide, payer les frais de labour pour entretenir  0, 25 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant et à crédit.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 30 000 francs CFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et son intérêt, aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en: The ten members of the BENKADI 5 group are married women, who are on average 35 years old and have on average 3 children, and who live for the most part in traditional families in N'TORLA, a village in the KOLOKOBA commune in the SIKASSO circle, the third administrative region of MALI. They are collaborating with microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to grow their agricultural businesses during the rainy season. They are on their seventh group loan with microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, and the previous loans were properly repaid. The crops grown are peanuts with Mrs. DIATA, standing on the left in the photo in this women’s group BENKADI 5. With this loan, she plans to buy one 50-kg sack of fertilizer and one container of herbicide and to pay for labor to maintain 0.25 hectares. After harvest, the goods are sold at the village in SIKASSO to a clientele composed of men and women for cash or credit. She plans to earn a monthly profit of 30,000 FCFA per season. This profit will allow her to repay her loan with interest and to help her husband with the family’s daily expenses.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and herbicide and to pay for labor

loans.name: Fasokadi 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe  FASOKADI 1 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 46 ans, ont en moyenne 6 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles traditionnelles à KOROBARRAGE un village dans la commune de KOUORO dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du MALI.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt de campagne avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est l’arachide avec madame ANTOU débout à la deuxième position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo dans ce groupe de femme  FASOKADI 1. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter 3 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 2 bidons d’herbicide, payer les frais de labour pour entretenir  0, 75 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant et à crédit.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 98 000 francs CFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et son intérêt, aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en: The ten members of the FASOKADI 1 group are married women, who are on average 46 years old and have on average 6 children, and who live for the most part in traditional families in KOUOROBARAGE, a village in the KOUORO commune in the SIKASSO circle, the third administrative region of MALI. They are collaborating with microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to build up their agricultural businesses during the rainy season. They are on their fourth seasonal loan with microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, and the previous loans were properly repaid. The crops grown are peanuts with Mrs. ANTOU, standing second from the left in the photo in this women’s group FASOKADI 1. With this loan, she plans to buy three 50-kg sacks of fertilizer and two containers of herbicide and to pay for labor to maintain 0.75 hectares. After harvest, the goods are sold at the village in SIKASSO to a clientele composed of men and women for cash or credit. She plans to earn a monthly profit of 98,000 FCFA per season. This profit will allow her to repay her loan with interest and to help her husband with the family’s daily expenses.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and herbicide and to pay for labor

loans.name: Sebeke Group

texts.fr:
Sebeke est un regroupement de femmes du quartier Koko de la ville de Koury qui se connaissent bien et qui vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 37 ans, sont mariées et ont au moins 4 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels que, Condiments, Plastiques, Produits cosmétiques, Friperies  et divers. Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de groupe. 
Fatoumata est un membre du groupe Sebeke  assise deuxième personne de droite à gauche, vendeuse de boissons (jus d’oranges, tamarin, bissap).  Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter au fur et à mesure ces fruits et légumes au marché en quantité et en qualité en vu de les transformer en boissons  qu’elle vend en détail  à une clientèle diverse. 
Tandis que les autres membres du groupe Sebeke comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 85 000FCFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle Mme Fatoumata compte réaliser  95 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses personnelles et augmenter son fonds de commerce. 
Elles souhaitent voir renforcer ce partenariat avec  Soro Yiriwaso pour que les stocks ne soient pas rares.
texts.en:
Sebeke is a women's group in the Koko neighborhood of the city of Koury. The women know one another well and live in large traditional families with their husbands, children, and other relatives. On average, they are 37 years old and have at least  four children.

This women’s group sells various items such as condiments, plastics, cosmetic products, second-hand clothing, etc.  In order to grow their business, the members decided to join Soro Yiriwaso’s loan program. This is their tenth group loan. 

Fatoumata is a member of the Sebeke group who is seated second from the right. She sells beverages (orange juice, tamarind juice, hibiscus juice). She will use her loan to buy a large quantity of high-quality fruits and vegetables that she will turn into juice. She sells these for retail to a diverse clientele. 

While the other members of the Sebeke group would like to earn an average profit of  85,000 FCFA during the loan cycle, Mme Fatoumata would like to earn 95,000 FCFA.  

In addition to repaying their loans, they use part of their revenue to pay for personal expenses and to grow their business. They would like to strengthen their partnership with Soro Yiriwaso so that they don’t run out of inventory.

loans.use: buy fruits and vegetables to make juice.

loans.name: Ankabenkelekan 8 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe Ankabenkelekan 8 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans, 4 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles traditionnelles à Fonfona, un des villages de Koutiala, 3ème région administrative du Mali. Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur neuvième prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est  le riz et l’arachide  avec Minata, assise au milieu sur la photo.
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des intrants, des semences, des petits matériels agricoles et payer les frais de labour et de sarclage pour entretenir  2 hectares. 
La production sera vendue au niveau du village et à Koutiala, après la récolte, à une clientèle mixte. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 205.000FCFA en fin de campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en: The ten members of the Ankabenkelekan 8 Group are married women with an average age of 38 and an average of four children each. They all live within traditional family frameworks in Fonfona, one of the villages of Koutiala, the third administrative region of Mali. They are collaborating with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution so that they can see through their agricultural activities during the winter period. This is their ninth loan with Soro Yiriwaso, with whom their previous loans were paid back in full. The group's main produce is rice and peanuts. The group's representative is Minata, the woman sitting in the middle of the front row in the photo. With this loan, she is planning on purchasing farming inputs, seeds and agricultural materials, as well as paying for the labour costs involved with hoeing two hectares of land. After the harvest, the produce will be sold on a village level as well as around Koutiala to a customer base made up of both men and woman. She is planning on making an average profit of 205,000 FCFA by the end of the season. These profits will allow her to pay off the loan. They will also allow her to aide her husband with their daily living expenses.

loans.use: to pay for labour costs, seeds, farming inputs and agricultural materials

loans.name: Kotognogontala 2 Group

texts.fr:
Les 7 membres du groupe KOTOGNOGONTALA 2 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans, ont en moyenne 5 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles traditionnelles à KOROBARRAGE un village dans la commune de KOUORO dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du MALI.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt de campagne avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est l’arachide avec madame BINTA débout à la première position de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo dans ce groupe de femme  KOTOGNOGONTALA 2. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter 2 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 1 bidon d’herbicide, payer les frais de labour pour entretenir  0,5 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant et à crédit.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 62 000 francs CFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et son intérêt, aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The seven members of the Kotognogontala 2 group are married women, who average 38 years of age and have an average of five children each; the majority of them live in traditional families in Korobarrage, a village in the Kouoro commune in the Sikasso circle (Mali's third administrative region).

They collaborate with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, in order to be able to carry out their farming activities successfully during the winter season, and they are on their fourth seasonal loan with the institution; the previous loans have all been repaid in full.

Binta, who is standing on the far right of the photo of the Kotognogontala 2 group of women, grows groundnut. With her loan she is planning to buy two 50 kilo sacks of fertilizer, a container of weed killer, and also pay for labor to maintain 0,5 hectares of land. 

Once harvested, the produce is sold in the village in Sikasso to a customer base made up of men and women, for cash and on credit.

Binta expects to make an average profit of 62,000FCFA per season. This will enable her to repay her loan and the interest on it, and also to help her husband with the daily expenses.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and weed killers and to pay for labor.

loans.name: Benkadi 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe BENKADI 1 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans, ont en moyenne 3 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles traditionnelles à TIBINA un village dans la commune de LOBOUGOULA dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du MALI.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur dixième prêt de campagne avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est l’arachide avec madame MARIAM débout à la deuxième position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo dans ce groupe de femme BENKADI 1. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter 2 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 2 bidons d’herbicide, payer les frais de labour pour entretenir  0, 75 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant et à crédit.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 85 000 francs CFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et son intérêt, aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Benkadi 1 group are married women who, on average, are 40 years old and have three children. They live for the most part in traditional families in Tibina, a village in Lobougoula, Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali. They are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better carry out their farming activities during the rainy season. They are on their tenth loan, and their previous loans have all been repaid. 

Mariam, who is standing second from the left in the photo, grows groundnuts. With her loan, she plans to buy two 50-kilogram sacs of fertilizer and two drums of herbicide. She will also pay the cost of labor to farm a 3/4 hectare of land. 

After the harvest, crops are sold in the village and in Sikasso to male and female customers for cash and credit. 

Mariam hopes to earn an average profit of 85,000 francs CFA per harvest. These earnings will allow her to pay back her loan and its interest and help her husband with the daily expenses.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and herbicide and to pay the cost of labor

loans.name: Benkadi 2 Group

texts.fr:
Les 7 membres du groupe BENKADI 2 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans, ont en moyenne 3 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles traditionnelles à TIBINA un village dans la commune de LOBOUGOULA dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du MALI.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur dixième prêt de campagne avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est l’arachide avec madame NIOGO débout à la deuxième position de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo dans ce groupe de femme BENKADI 2. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter 2 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 2 bidons d’herbicide, payer les frais de labour pour entretenir  0, 75 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant et à crédit.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 85 000 francs CFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et son intérêt, aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The seven members of the Benkadi 2 group are married women who are on average 36 years old with three children. Most of them live in traditional families in Tibina, a village in the Lobougoula commune in the Sikasso circle of the third administrative region of Mali.
They collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institute in order to manage their farming affairs during the winter.
This is their tenth agricultural loan with the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution, the previous loans were repaid correctly.
Mrs. Niogo, who is standing second from the left in the group of Benkadi 2 women in the photo, grows groundnuts.
With her loan she plans to buy two sacks of 50 kg of fertilizer, two cans of weed killer, and to pay for labour costs for 0.75 hectares.
After harvesting, she sells the production in her village, in Sikasso, to a mixed clientele for cash and for credit.
She plans to make an average monthly profit of 85,000 francs CFA per field.
This profit will enable her to repay her loan with the interests and to help her husband with the daily expenses.

loans.use: to purchase fertiliser, weed killer,and to pay labour costs.
